Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI:Examining Visual Processing in Infants from Monolingual and Bilingual Environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Infants from bilingual environments must overcome learning challenges beyond those faced by monolinguals, including the need to rapidly categorize linguistic input and to discover unique properties of multiple languages. This project will add to the literature exploring how bilingual infants accomplish this feat. Continued research on this topic is essential, as bilinguals are a majority in the world, but remain a minority in research on early development. One body of work suggests that very early bilingual experience may instill cognitive benefits, which in turn helps infants navigate multilingual environments. Many of the tasks used in these studies entail rapid visual processing, which may be one source of the observed bilingual advantages. Bilinguals must index their language input using numerous speech cues, including subtle differences in mouth movements across languages. Early experience identifying these visual cues in language may hone bilinguals? visual processing. To investigate this possibility, monolingual and bilingual infants will complete tasks that assess several language-relevant aspects of visual processing. This project will be undertaken in collaboration with Dr. Leher Singh at the National University of Singapore. As a diverse, multilingual country, Singapore is an ideal location for research on bilingualism, and will facilitate this investigation of cognitive development in bilingual environments.

Early experience processing multiple languages may enhance visual short-term memory (VSTM) and visual selective attention (VSA) in infancy. VSTM encodes and retrieves visual features over short intervals. Bilingual processing may require VSTM to exploit the dynamic, rapidly changing details relevant for language discrimination. Categorizing language input in real time may also require infants to employ flexible VSA to discover the visual cues that identify each language. Continual use of these systems for language categorization may advance bilingual infants? domain-general VSTM and VSA, facilitating continued bilingual acquisition. In the current project, infant VSTM will be examined with a color change detection task. In this task, object color must be remembered across a brief delay in order to detect a change. VSA will be assessed with an object categorization task. Infants? ability to identify features that are diagnostic of an object?s category membership will be evaluated. We will use infrared eye-tracking to measure infants? success in both tasks. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dylan Antovich completed research on infant visual learning as part of his participation in the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes (EAPSI), funded by the National Science Foundation and the Singaporean National Research Foundation. As a participant in EAPSI, Mr. Antovich traveled to Singapore in the summer of 2015 to collaborate with Dr. Leher Singh at the National University of Singapore. During his stay in Singapore, Mr. Antovich tested 6-month-old infants while investigating the effects of bilingual experience on infant visual learning. Infants in bilingual environments must discover the dual nature of their language input, rapidly categorize incoming speech, and learn each of their languages from less exposure than monolinguals. Despite these challenges, bilingual infants tend to reach language milestones around the same time as monolinguals. Recent research suggests that early experience with two languages may confer cognitive benefits in infancy, which in turn could help learners navigate multilingual environments. Infant visual processing may be influenced by bilingual experience, due to bilinguals’ reliance on visual cues to help determine which language they are hearing as they process speech.

The present study assessed whether 6-month-olds from bilingual homes in Singapore demonstrate an advantage in processing visual information. In two tasks we tested infants’ ability to store visual information in memory over brief intervals and to deploy attention efficiently while learning visual regularities. The data suggest that infants from bilingual homes demonstrate a visual processing advantage relative to monolingual infants tested in past work. This may be due to bilinguals’ reliance on these faculties to process the mouth movements that accompany speech, an important cue for language categorization in infancy. This line of work will continue to probe whether this bilingual advantage is attributable to cognitive benefits of bilingualism in general, to specific language pairings present in Singapore, or to other cultural differences between countries.

In addition to providing the opportunity to conduct this research, the EAPSI program has allowed Mr. Antovich to learn more about Singaporean culture and to develop a cross-national collaboration with researchers there. This network will facilitate the completion of research addressing important questions relevant to our understanding of language and cognitive development. International collaborations are important in the field of human development, as they foster research that is generalizable beyond populations typically studied in the U.S. This is particularly important in the context of bilingual language acquisition, which represents a small portion of language research even though a majority of individuals world-wide acquire two or more languages. In summary, the EAPSI program is invaluable in maintaining a global scientific community, and will help to promote science and improve our understanding of the world and the diverse peoples that inhabit it.
